__label__society AP sources: Jail guards at time of Epstein death reject deal WASHINGTON (AP) ‚Äî Federal prosecutors offered a plea deal to two correctional officers responsible for guarding Jeffrey Epstein on the night of his death, but the officers have declined the offer, people familiar with the matter told The Associated Press. The existence of the plea offer signals the Justice Department is considering criminal charges in connection with the wealthy financier‚Äôs death at the Metropolitan Correctional Center in New York in August. The city‚Äôs medical examiner ruled Epstein‚Äôs death a suicide. The guards on Epstein‚Äôs unit are suspected of failing to check on him every half hour, as required, and of fabricating log entries to show they had. As part of the proposed plea deal, prosecutors wanted the guards to admit they falsified the prison records, according to the people familiar with the matter. They spoke on the condition of anonymity because they were not permitted to publicly discuss the investigation. The U.S. attorney‚Äôs office in Manhattan had no comment on the plea offer. Both guards were working overtime because of staffing shortages. They have been placed on administrative leave while the FBI and the Justice Department‚Äôs inspector general investigate the circumstances surrounding Epstein‚Äôs death. The 66-year-old had been awaiting trial on charges of sexually abusing teenage girls. Epstein was placed on suicide watch after he was found on his cell floor July 23 with bruises on his neck. Multiple people familiar with operations at the jail have said Epstein was then taken off suicide watch about a week before his death, meaning he was less closely monitored but still supposed to be checked on every 30 minutes. Epstein‚Äôs death exposed mounting evidence that the chronically understaffed Metropolitan Correctional Center may have bungled its responsibility to keep him alive. Guards often work overtime day after day, and other employees are pressed into service as correctional officers. Falsification of records has been a problem throughout the federal prison system. Kathleen Hawk Sawyer, who was named director of the Bureau of Prisons after Epstein‚Äôs death, disclosed in a Nov. 4 internal memo that a review of operations across the agency found some staff members failed to perform required rounds and inmate counts but logged that they had done so anyway. ‚ÄúFalsification of information in government systems and documents is also a violation of policy, and may be subject to criminal prosecution as well,‚Äù Hawk Sawyer wrote in the memo to top prison officials, a copy of which was obtained by the AP. The memo also noted that staff members who are indicted by a grand jury will be placed on an indefinite, unpaid suspension until the resolution of the criminal case. Epstein‚Äôs ability to take his own life while incarcerated at one of the most secure jails in America ended the possibility of a trial that would have involved prominent figures. And it sparked widespread anger that he wouldn‚Äôt have to answer for the allegations. He had pleaded not guilty and was preparing to argue that he could not be charged because of a 2008 deal he made to avoid federal prosecution on similar allegations. The Justice Department has vowed to aggressively investigate and bring charges against anyone who may have helped Epstein. Federal prosecutors investigating the financier‚Äôs death subpoenaed up to 20 staff members at the jail in August. Attorney General William Barr ‚Äî who has said investigators found ‚Äúserious irregularities‚Äù at the jail ‚Äî said the FBI‚Äôs investigation had been slowed because some witnesses had been uncooperative. In addition to the shakeup at the top of the Bureau of Prisons, the warden at the Metropolitan Correctional Center had also been reassigned to a desk post at a regional office.
__label__entertainment Ariana Grande Warns Fans She Might Have To Cancel A Show Due To Her Health Ariana Grande is giving an update on the condition of her health. The 26-year-old singer has been struggling with being sick for the past month, since she last performed in London, England, back in October. Now, Ariana is giving fans a warning, should she need to cancel a show because of the pain she‚Äôs in. ‚Äúso i‚Äôm stull very sick. i‚Äôve been sick since the last london show. i don‚Äôt know how it‚Äôs possible but my throat and head are still in so much pain,‚Äù she wrote in a note on Instagram story. ‚Äúi sound okay i‚Äôm just in a lot of pain and it‚Äôs difficult to breath during the show. i am seeing my doctor and trying my v best to get better for tomorrow‚Äôs show. the last thing i would ever want to do is cancel a show at this point with so few left. i‚Äôm truly cherishing every moment of this.‚Äù ‚Äúi just really don‚Äôt know what‚Äôs happening with my body right now and need to figure it out. please take this as a gentle heads up,‚Äù Ariana continued. ‚Äúi don‚Äôt want anyone to feel blindsided tomorrow if god forbid i can‚Äôt make the show happen.‚Äù ‚Äúlove you with all my heart and will keep you posted,‚Äù she concluded. Ariana is next scheduled to perform in Lexington, Ky., on Sunday (November 17).
__label__technology researchers create bulletproof 3D printed cubes using complex patterns researchers at rice university in houston have used 3D printing methods to create polymer cubes that can withstand bullets. made up of numerous layers of different patterns, the cubes‚Äô elaborate structure makes them ultra-durable. the group of 12 researchers found that the cubes with these particular structures were significantly better at withstanding the impact of a 5.8 kilometre-per-second bullet (close to 13,000 miles per hour) and other ‚Äòcrushing forces‚Äô than a solid cube made of the same polymer. the plastic cubes remain almost wholly intact when shot at by the bullet or impacted by other ‚Äòcrushing forces‚Äô. images courtesy of rice university detailed in a recently published paper in the small journal, the rice university researchers discovered that scaling up these complex patterns and structures and recreating them using 3D printers did not effect their properties. like strength and extreme compressibility, despite being rigid structures. the patterns are based on tubulanes ‚Äî theoretical microscopic structures made of crosslinked carbon nanotubes that were predicted to have impressive properties, like strength and extreme compressibility, in 1993 by chemist ray baughman and physicist douglas galv√£o. each crisscross or zigzag pattern is strategically calculated and engineered to give the objects incredible strength. the researchers blasted two cubes‚Äîone made from solid polymer, and one made from a polymer printed with a tubulane structure. whilst the solid polymer block was damaged with a huge dent and cracks, the other cube stopped the bullet by its second layer, leaving the rest of it completely intact and undamaged. the assumption is that a porous structure reduces an object‚Äôs stopping power, but in practice, the complex polymer lattice in these cubes makes them able to compress and collapse to absorb the kinetic energy of an impact and contain the resulting damage so that it only affects a minimal area. it demonstrates that cheaper polymers could be used instead of metal or ceramics to create durable parts or components. a material such as this could be used in various applications such as aerospace, architecture, or even military. project info research body:rice universitypaper: 3D printed tubulanes as lightweight hypervelocity impact resistant structuresauthors: seyed mohammad sajadi, cristiano f. woellner, prathyush ramesh, shannon l. eichmann, qiushi sun, peter j. boul, carl j. thaemlitz, muhammad m. rahman, ray h. baughman douglas s. galv√£o, chandra sekhar tiwary, pulickel m. ajayansource: gizmodo
__label__not_news Why You Need To Visit Australia‚Äôs Free-Thinking Town Of Fremantle Now A picturesque port city in Western Australia, Fremantle may not be at the top of most travelers‚Äô Aussie itineraries‚Äîbut it should be. Charming, dynamic, creative and with a wealth of fascinating history, it‚Äôs one of those under-the-radar gems that intrepid travelers love to discover. Only a 30-minute drive from Perth (another Aussie city that deserves more attention), the town of less than 10,000 is an unconventional, can‚Äôt-quite-put-you-finger-on-it mix of captivating people and sites that you can‚Äôt help but find yourself falling in love with. Here are just some of the attractions that will have you enchanted with this quirky corner of Australia. Ok, Ok. Ranking a prison as a city‚Äôs main attraction may not exactly seem in line with Fremantle‚Äôs image of a friendly, welcoming spot. But that‚Äôs all the more reason to come visit and see for yourself how this town of many personalities never fails to charm. Fremantle Prison is a UNESCO World Heritage Site (the only building with such a designation in Western Australia). Built by prisoners in the 1850s the foreboding setting was notorious for its cruel treatment of its unfortunate inhabitants. Sadly, it‚Äôs also where more than 40 inmates met their maker in the prison‚Äôs gallows. Tours are available, with the ‚ÄúTorchlight‚Äù night tour sure to give you nightmares thanks to its reputation for ghost sightings. Better yet, check out the jail and the town as well with Michael Deller of Fremantle Tours. Deller‚Äôs love for his hometown is infectious and his knowledge is unparalleled. Dating back to the late 1800‚Äôs, this historic Fremantle site has a much more welcoming reputation than the nearby prison. Inside you‚Äôll be greeted by the boisterous cries of over 150 merchants selling an eye-catching spectrum of food, fashion, art, jewellery and more. The market is a Fremantle institution and is as much about visiting with friends and neighbors over a slice of honey cake as it is about shopping. Visitors to the city will find the market an ideal place to tap into Fremantle‚Äôs vibe and get great tips from locals about where to eat and stay. Cappuccino Strip Named for the street‚Äôs incredible number of Italian restaurants (Fremantle has a strong history of Italian immigration), this lively, pretty promenade is one of the city‚Äôs main arteries. Lined with restaurants, locally-owned brew pubs, bookstores (that offer enticing ‚Äúblind dates‚Äù) and bars, a walk along this main drag is a must-do when in Fremantle. Many of Fremantle‚Äôs true gems, however, are found by wandering down the many side streets that span outward from the strip. Let your curiosity lead the way and you‚Äôll soon be stumbling upon lovely Aboriginal and local art galleries, clothing stores, coffee shops, boutique hotels and more. There are lots of wonderful eateries off the main street as well; try Kuld Creamery, ¬†Bread In Common, Cos Baby and Strange Company, just to name a few. The Art Arguably, there is nothing that quite captures the mysterious magic, the je-ne-sais-quoi of Fremantle and its citizens as the incredibly dazzling kaleidoscope of street art that seems to await you around every corner. From an homage to an endangered species, to an intricate microcosm of community, to portraits of beauty that are meant to startle and provoke, there seems to be an engaging form of artwork in nearly every nook and cranny of the city, each one more stunning, intriguing and thought-provoking than the last. Bathers Beach Even if you don‚Äôt consider yourself an art aficionado, you‚Äôre sure to agree that Fremantle‚Äôs Bathers Beach is a work of art. With its gorgeous white sands and gentle undulating waves, it‚Äôs a perfect (if small) spot for the whole family to enjoy some sun and surf. Head to nearby Bathers Beach House restaurant to dine on delicious fresh food just steps from the beach as you toast the sunset with some tasty Australian sparkling.
__label__economy –ö–æ—Ñ–µ–π–Ω—è Beggroff Bakery –≤ –æ—Å–æ–±–Ω—è–∫–µ XVIII –≤–µ–∫–∞ –Ω–∞ –ù–µ–≤—Å–∫–æ–º –∑–∞–∫—Ä—ã–ª–∞—Å—å —Å–ø—É—Å—Ç—è –¥–≤–∞ –º–µ—Å—è—Ü–∞ —Ä–∞–±–æ—Ç—ã –ö–æ—Ñ–µ–π–Ω—è¬†Beggroff Bakery –≤ –æ—Å–æ–±–Ω—è–∫–µ –ë–µ–≥–≥—Ä–æ–≤—ã—Ö –Ω–∞ –ù–µ–≤—Å–∫–æ–º –ø—Ä–æ—Å–ø–µ–∫—Ç–µ, 62, –ø–æ—Å—Ç—Ä–æ–µ–Ω–Ω–æ–º –≤ XVIII –≤–µ–∫–µ, –∑–∞–∫—Ä—ã–ª–∞—Å—å. –û–± —ç—Ç–æ–º —Å–æ–æ–±—â–∏–ª–∏ –≤ –∏–Ω—Å—Ç–∞–≥—Ä–∞–º–µ –ø—Ä–æ–µ–∫—Ç–∞, –Ω–µ –æ–±—ä—è—Å–Ω–∏–≤ –ø—Ä–∏—á–∏–Ω—É. –ó–∞–≤–µ–¥–µ–Ω–∏–µ –ø—Ä–æ—Ä–∞–±–æ—Ç–∞–ª–æ –æ–∫–æ–ª–æ –¥–≤—É—Ö –º–µ—Å—è—Ü–µ–≤. –í –∫–æ–º–∞–Ω–¥–µ –ø–µ—Ç–µ—Ä–±—É—Ä–≥—Å–∫–æ–≥–æ —Ä–µ—Å—Ç–æ—Ä–∞–Ω–∞ Kroo Cafe, –∫–æ—Ç–æ—Ä–∞—è –∑–∞–ø—É—Å–∫–∞–ª–∞ –∫–æ—Ñ–µ–π–Ω—é, –ø–æ–¥—Ç–≤–µ—Ä–¥–∏–ª–∏¬†¬´–ë—É–º–∞–≥–µ¬ª –∑–∞–∫—Ä—ã—Ç–∏–µ –∑–∞–≤–µ–¥–µ–Ω–∏—è, –Ω–æ –æ—Ç–∫–∞–∑–∞–ª–∏—Å—å –Ω–∞–∑—ã–≤–∞—Ç—å –ø—Ä–∏—á–∏–Ω—É.¬†¬´–ù–µ –¥—É–º–∞—é, —á—Ç–æ —Å –≤–∞–º–∏ –∫—Ç–æ-—Ç–æ –∑–∞—Ö–æ—á–µ—Ç –ø–æ —ç—Ç–æ–º—É –ø–æ–≤–æ–¥—É –≥–æ–≤–æ—Ä–∏—Ç—å. –≠—Ç–æ –Ω–µ –æ—á–µ–Ω—å –ø—Ä–∏—è—Ç–Ω–æ–µ —Å–æ–±—ã—Ç–∏–µ¬ª,¬†‚Äî —Å–∫–∞–∑–∞–ª–∞ –ø—Ä–µ–¥—Å—Ç–∞–≤–∏—Ç–µ–ª—å–Ω–∏—Ü–∞ –ø—Ä–æ–µ–∫—Ç–∞. Beggroff Bakery –∑–∞—Ä–∞–±–æ—Ç–∞–ª–∞ –Ω–∞ –ù–µ–≤—Å–∫–æ–º –ø—Ä–æ—Å–ø–µ–∫—Ç–µ –≤ –∫–æ–Ω—Ü–µ –∞–≤–≥—É—Å—Ç–∞ 2019 –≥–æ–¥–∞. –ü–æ—Å–ª–µ–¥–Ω–∏–µ –ø–æ—Å—Ç—ã –≤ —Å–æ—Ü—Å–µ—Ç—è—Ö –∑–∞–≤–µ–¥–µ–Ω–∏—è –¥–∞—Ç–∏—Ä—É—é—Ç—Å—è –∫–æ–Ω—Ü–æ–º –æ–∫—Ç—è–±—Ä—è. –°–æ–∑–¥–∞—Ç–µ–ª–∏ –ø—Ä–æ–µ–∫—Ç–∞ —Å–æ–æ–±—â–∞–ª–∏, —á—Ç–æ¬†–∫–æ—Ñ–µ–π–Ω—è –±—ã–ª–∞ –æ—Ä–∏–µ–Ω—Ç–∏—Ä–æ–≤–∞–Ω–∞ –Ω–∞ –∂–∏—Ç–µ–ª—è –º–µ–≥–∞–ø–æ–ª–∏—Å–∞, —Ä–∞–∑–±–∏—Ä–∞—é—â–µ–≥–æ—Å—è –≤ –∫–∞—á–µ—Å—Ç–≤–µ –ø—Ä–æ–¥—É–∫—Ç–∞ –∏ –æ–±–ª–∞–¥–∞—é—â–µ–≥–æ –∏–∑—ã—Å–∫–∞–Ω–Ω—ã–º –≤–∫—É—Å–æ–º. –ü—Ä–æ–¥—É–∫—Ü–∏—é –∑–∞–≤–µ–¥–µ–Ω–∏—è –∏–∑–≥–æ—Ç–∞–≤–ª–∏–≤–∞–ª–∏ –Ω–∞ —Å–æ–±—Å—Ç–≤–µ–Ω–Ω–æ–π —Ñ–∞–±—Ä–∏–∫–µ. –ß–∞—Å—Ç—å –º–µ–Ω—é –±—ã–ª–∞ —Ä–∞–∑—Ä–∞–±–æ—Ç–∞–Ω–∞ —Ä—É–∫–æ–≤–æ–¥—Å—Ç–≤–æ–º —Ñ—Ä–∞–Ω—Ü—É–∑—Å–∫–æ–≥–æ –º–∞—Å—Ç–µ—Ä–∞ –õ–æ—Ä–∞–Ω–∞ –ú–æ—Ä–µ–Ω–æ –¥–ª—è —Ä–µ—Å—Ç–æ—Ä–∞–Ω–∞ Kroo Cafe. –°—Ä–µ–¥–∏ –ø–æ–∑–∏—Ü–∏–π –±—ã–ª–∏¬†—Å—ã—Ç–Ω—ã–µ –∫—Ä—É–∞—Å—Å–∞–Ω—ã —Å —Ä–æ—Å—Ç–±–∏—Ñ–æ–º –∏ –ª–æ—Å–æ—Å–µ–º, —ç–∫–ª–µ—Ä—ã, —Ñ—Ä–∞–Ω—Ü—É–∑—Å–∫–∏–µ –º–∞–∫–∞—Ä–æ–Ω—ã –∏ –¥—Ä—É–≥–∏–µ –¥–µ—Å–µ—Ä—Ç—ã. –í –∑–∞–≤–µ–¥–µ–Ω–∏–∏ –º–æ–∂–Ω–æ –±—ã–ª–æ –ø–æ–ø—Ä–æ–±–æ–≤–∞—Ç—å –ª–∞—Ç—Ç–µ —Å —Ö–∞–ª–≤–æ–π, –∞–ø–µ–ª—å—Å–∏–Ω–æ–≤—ã–π —Ä–∞—Ñ, –Ω–µ—Å–∫–æ–ª—å–∫–æ –≤–∏–¥–æ–≤ –ª–∏–º–æ–Ω–∞–¥–æ–≤ –∏ —á–∞—è. –ö –∫–æ—Ñ–µ –ø–æ–¥–∞–≤–∞–ª–∏ –±–ª—é–¥—Ü–µ —Å–æ –≤–∑–±–∏—Ç—ã–º–∏ —Å–ª–∏–≤–∫–∞–º–∏.
__label__science Scientists Have Created an 'Unsinkable' Metal That Floats Even When Damaged It took just 2 1/2 hours for the Titanic to sink after it collided with an iceberg in 1912. Before the disaster, the ship was said to be unsinkable thanks to the design of its below-deck compartments. But the Titanic's engineers hadn't anticipated that a disaster would puncture six of those compartments. More than a century later, ships still aren't impervious to collisions: In May, 28 people died when a sightseeing boat and a cruise ship collided on the Danube River in Hungary. And in 2017, a US Navy destroyer collided with an oil tanker, killing 10 Navy sailors. But new research from the University of Rochester may offer a novel way to keep vessels afloat. A team there has designed a metal array that won't sink, even after it's pierced. ``Regardless how much it's damaged or punctured, it will still be able to stay afloat,`` Chunlei Guo, the study's chief researcher, told Business Insider. The project received grants from the US Army, the National Science Foundation, and the Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation, the private charity started by the Microsoft co-founder Bill Gates and his wife, Melinda. In addition to ship construction, the researchers think the metal could one day be used for a host of other applications like cleaning latrines or building floating cities. Ships float by displacing water; to remain afloat, a ship must weigh less than the volume of water it displaces. When the Titanic's compartments flooded, the ship became heavier than the displaced water and started sinking. To prevent their metal structure from suffering the same fate, the Rochester researchers had to design a method to constantly push water away. The scientists used lasers to carve tiny grooves into the surface of an aluminium disk. These etchings trapped air, forming a protective barrier that caused water droplets to slide off the metal surface. But if the metal was held underwater long enough, the grooves would eventually fill up with water instead of air, the researchers found. So they placed two of the etched metal disks on either end of a small pillar, with the etched sides facing inward. They left a gap in the centre that's small enough to prevent water from entering. That creates an air bubble that helps the array to float. Next, the researchers kept the array underwater with extra weight for two months to see whether it would lose its buoyancy. But when they took the weight off, the metal still rose to the surface. Their final task was to see whether the array could sustain major damage. So they drilled holes in the disks and placed them underwater again. No matter how many holes they drilled, they found, the array would still float. In the new study, Guo suggests using the metal to build life rafts, buoyant clothing, or ``highly floatable ships and vessels``. The weight of the ship wouldn't matter, he said, as long as the surface area of the metal was large enough to counterbalance it. ``As the area of the metal becomes larger and larger, so does the loading capacity,`` Guo said. That means the metal could one day even be used to build giant structures like floating cities. ``I think it's a great idea,`` Guo said, adding that his metal configuration was ``far more robust and far more durable`` than some other materials associated with floating-city concepts, like fibreglass or limestone. Guo's research has also shown that just a few droplets of water are sufficient to rid the metal of dirt. So he's been working with the Gates Foundation to understand how these properties could improve sanitation in developing countries. Latrines made out of similar etched metal, for example, could be easier to clean. ``Keeping the metal afloat is just one of the many, many applications,`` Guo said. Right now, the biggest obstacle to producing the metal in larger quantities is that the laser etching takes a while ‚Äì about an hour to etch a 1-inch-by-1-inch square. But Guo said that's a problem for manufacturers to solve. His mission, he added, is to demonstrate the science. This article was originally published by Business Insider. More from Business Insider:
__label__technology –ó–∞ —à–æ–ø–∏–Ω–≥–æ–º ‚Äì –≤ —Å–º–∞—Ä—Ç—Ñ–æ–Ω –£—Ä–∞–ª—å—Ü—ã –≤—Å–µ —á–∞—â–µ –ø–æ–∫—É–ø–∞—é—Ç –º–æ–±–∏–ª—å–Ω—ã–µ —É—Å—Ç—Ä–æ–π—Å—Ç–≤–∞ –∏ –∞–∫—Å–µ—Å—Å—É–∞—Ä—ã —Å–æ —Å–º–∞—Ä—Ç—Ñ–æ–Ω–∞. –ê–Ω–∞–ª–∏—Ç–∏–∫–∏ –ú–µ–≥–∞–§–æ–Ω–∞ –∑–∞—Ñ–∏–∫—Å–∏—Ä–æ–≤–∞–ª–∏: –¥–≤–µ —Ç—Ä–µ—Ç–∏ –ø–æ–∫—É–ø–æ–∫ (61%) –≤ –∏–Ω—Ç–µ—Ä–Ω–µ—Ç-–º–∞–≥–∞–∑–∏–Ω–µ –æ–ø–µ—Ä–∞—Ç–æ—Ä–∞ –≤ —ç—Ç–æ–º –≥–æ–¥—É –±—ã–ª–∏ –ø—Ä–æ—Å–º–æ—Ç—Ä–µ–Ω—ã –∏ –æ—Ñ–æ—Ä–º–ª–µ–Ω—ã –∏–º–µ–Ω–Ω–æ —Å –ø–æ–º–æ—â—å—é –º–æ–±–∏–ª—å–Ω–æ–≥–æ —Ç–µ–ª–µ—Ñ–æ–Ω–∞. –≠—Ç–æ –Ω–∞ 11% –±–æ–ª—å—à–µ –ø—Ä–æ—à–ª–æ–≥–æ –≥–æ–¥–∞. 36% –∑–∞–∫–∞–∑–æ–≤ –ø–æ—Å—Ç—É–ø–∞—é—Ç —Å –∫–æ–º–ø—å—é—Ç–µ—Ä–∞, –æ—Å—Ç–∞–ª—å–Ω—ã–µ –ø—Ä–∏—Ö–æ–¥—è—Ç—Å—è –Ω–∞ –ø–ª–∞–Ω—à–µ—Ç—ã. –ò–Ω—Ç–µ—Ä–µ—Å–Ω–æ, —á—Ç–æ —Å –Ω–∞—á–∞–ª–∞ –≥–æ–¥–∞ –∂–µ–Ω—â–∏–Ω—ã (43%) –ø—Ä–∏–±–ª–∏–∑–∏–ª–∏—Å—å –∫ –º—É–∂—á–∏–Ω–∞–º (57%) –≤ –º–æ–±–∏–ª—å–Ω–æ–º –æ–Ω–ª–∞–π–Ω-—à–æ–ø–∏–Ω–≥–µ –∏ —Å—Ç–∞–ª–∏ –∞–∫—Ç–∏–≤–Ω–µ–µ –ø–æ–ª—å–∑–æ–≤–∞—Ç—å—Å—è –≤–∏—Ç—Ä–∏–Ω–æ–π –ú–µ–≥–∞–§–æ–Ω–∞. –ï–∂–µ–¥–Ω–µ–≤–Ω–æ —Å–æ—Ç—Ä—É–¥–Ω–∏–∫–∏ –∏–Ω—Ç–µ—Ä–Ω–µ—Ç-–º–∞–≥–∞–∑–∏–Ω–∞ –ú–µ–≥–∞–§–æ–Ω–∞ –ø—Ä–∏–Ω–∏–º–∞—é—Ç –≤ —Å—Ä–µ–¥–Ω–µ–º 100 –∑–∞–∫–∞–∑–æ–≤. –ü–æ –∞–∫—Ç–∏–≤–Ω–æ—Å—Ç–∏ –∑–∞–∫–∞–∑–æ–≤ –≤ –∏–Ω—Ç–µ—Ä–Ω–µ—Ç-–º–∞–≥–∞–∑–∏–Ω–µ –≤ —ç—Ç–æ–º –≥–æ–¥—É –ü–µ—Ä–º—Å–∫–∏–π –∫—Ä–∞–π –≤–æ—à–µ–ª –≤ –¢–û–ü-5 —Ä–µ–≥–∏–æ–Ω–æ–≤ –Ω–∞ –£—Ä–∞–ª–µ, –Ω–æ –ø–æ–∫–∞ –ø–∞–ª—å–º—É –ø–µ—Ä–≤–µ–Ω—Å—Ç–≤–∞ –¥–µ—Ä–∂–∞—Ç –∂–∏—Ç–µ–ª–∏ –°–≤–µ—Ä–¥–ª–æ–≤—Å–∫–æ–π –æ–±–ª–∞—Å—Ç–∏. –ò–Ω—Ç–µ—Ä–Ω–µ—Ç-–º–∞–≥–∞–∑–∏–Ω –ê–û ¬´–ú–µ–≥–∞–§–æ–Ω –†–∏—Ç–µ–π–ª¬ª, www.shop.megafon.ru, –û–ì–†–ù 1027809220317.
__label__technology Android Circuit: New Galaxy S11 Leaks, Moto Razr's Radical Fold, Samsung's Mysterious Screen Taking a look back at seven days of news and headlines across the world of Android, this week‚Äôs Android Circuit includes the latest Galaxy S11 leaks, Samsung‚Äôs mysterious screen, Sony‚Äôs curved Xperia, the return of the Moto Razr, a hands-on review of the Mi Note 10, and Android gestures face up to the navigation keys.Android Circuit is here to remind you of a few of the many things that have happened around Android in the last week (and you can find the weekly Apple news digest here). Galaxy S11 Details Framed By SnapDragon 865 Capabilities Details are slowly coming out regarding the Galaxy S11 specifications, and it‚Äôs not just Samsung sources that are kicking in. The latest details about Qualcomm‚Äôs Snapdragon 865 system on chip that is expected to power the South Korean flagship also help frame the specs of the smartphone, as I reported earlier this week: More here on Forbes. What Is The Mysterious SAMOLED Screen? Then there‚Äôs Samsung‚Äôs own documentation helping out. Although no technical details were revealed, trademark applications for the term SAMOLED in connection with displays suitable for smartphones were published, giving an indication as to another key feature of the Galaxy S11. What could the ‚ÄôS‚Äô signify? Could it be speed? Or shape? Read more details here. Sony‚Äôs Curved Xperia 3 Also expected to sport the SnapDragon 865 is the next Xperia handset from Sony. Reports from China label the handset as the Sony Xperia 3. The leaked information also details the slightly curved backplate that will give the smartphone its own identity.¬†GSM Arena has more details: Return Of The Razr The Moto Razr is back, with roughly the same form factor as the 2004 original, but now the flip is a folding screen. Closed you have the classic form factor, open you have a tall but normal feeling Android screen. With an easel fold in the screen, the new Razr is wildly different to the Galaxy Fold.¬†Myriam Joire has the hands on experience: More at GeekSpin. A Closer Look At The Xiaomi Mi Note 10 Xiaomi return to the phablet form factor with the Mi Note 10. The 6.47 inch screened smartphone‚Äôs standout feature is the camera. It comes with a massive 108 megapixel sensor on the main camera, supported by four other lenses at the rear.¬†Tom Bedford has a hands on with the device: More at TechRadar. And Finally‚Ä¶ Google‚Äôs move to Android 10 includes the adoption of gestures as the main navigation controls while depreciating the on screen navigation bar. Reddit‚Äôs Android community has been discussing the choices and impacts of the two systems: The full discussion can be found over at Reddit. Android Circuit rounds up the news from the Android world every weekend here on Forbes. Don‚Äôt forget to follow me so you don‚Äôt miss any coverage in the future, and of course read the sister column in Apple Loop! Last week‚Äôs Android Circuit can be found here, and if you have any news and links you‚Äôd like to see featured in Android Circuit, get in touch!
__label__society 1 dead after two-vehicle crash on Hwy 27 in Davenport POLK COUNTY, Fla. --- One person is dead after a crash on US Hwy 27 in Polk County. The Polk County Sheriff's Office said they are investigating the crash that happened on US Hwy 27 at Central Grove Road in Davenport. POLK NEWS | The latest headlines from Polk County Officials said the two-vehicle crash happened around 5:53 p.m. They said 54-year-old Jose Febo-Collazo died from his injuries, and 52-year-old Sandra Mendez-Pagan was transported to a local hospital. Mendez-Pagan is in stable condition. Witnesses say Febo-Callazo stopped at a stop sign on Central Grove Road, but then proceeded onto the highway into the path of Mendez-Pagan. Mendez-Pagan struck Febo-Callazo's driver side door and both vehicles spun. His car then began burning. He was extracted from the vehicle and taken to the hospital, but he later died from his injuries. Southbound Hwy 27 was shutdown at California Blvd. for four hours after the crash.
__label__society Don‚Äôt Pass Death Penalty For Hate Speech Into Law, Soyinka Tells NASS Nobel laureate, Prof Wole Soyinka, has written to the National Assembly over the consequence of passing a bill stipulating death penalty for hate speech. He said this in his letter to Nigerian lawmakers. Recall that the bill was sponsored by the Deputy Chief Whip, Senator Aliyu Sabi Abdullahi (Niger North), and has already passed the first reading at the Senate. However, Soyinka said he will never be in support of fake news and hate speech but a death penalty was not acceptable to him. He said, ‚ÄúIt is no fake news that I have denounced the purveyors of public lies and hate material as the very scum of the earth. I have called them names that come close to enrolling me among the very reprobates we all so fervently denounce.¬† ‚ÄúI have utilised every available platform to highlight their perverse mentality and call for concerted action against their hyper-activism against humanity in general. ‚ÄúI have singled out the Nigerian species of this criminal pursuit as an especially virulent breed, as a subhuman aberration without conscience, incapable of remorse, sustained by abnormal reserves of sadism. ‚ÄúI have closed down dozens of fake sites instituted over my name, and set in motion mechanisms for the pursuit of those who steal my identity, even where the content is quite harmless, even positive. ‚ÄúAs you may have discerned so far, I again, and unapologetically, exploit this very development to reiterate my detestation and contempt for such pestilences that plague our humanity.‚Äù Soyinka implored the lawmakers to find another way to resolve the issues at hand other than passing into law of death sentence.
__label__society –ö–∞–±–º–∏–Ω –æ–ø—Ä–µ–¥–µ–ª–∏–ª –ø–æ–±–µ–¥–∏—Ç–µ–ª—è –≤ –∫–æ–Ω–∫—É—Ä—Å–µ –Ω–∞ –¥–æ–ª–∂–Ω–æ—Å—Ç—å –≥–ª–∞–≤—ã –£–∫—Ä–∞–≤—Ç–æ–¥–æ—Ä–∞ –ö–∞–±–º–∏–Ω –æ–ø—Ä–µ–¥–µ–ª–∏–ª –ø–æ–±–µ–¥–∏—Ç–µ–ª—è –≤ –∫–æ–Ω–∫—É—Ä—Å–µ –Ω–∞ –¥–æ–ª–∂–Ω–æ—Å—Ç—å –≥–ª–∞–≤—ã –£–∫—Ä–∞–≤—Ç–æ–¥–æ—Ä–∞. –†—É–∫–æ–≤–æ–¥–∏—Ç–µ–ª–µ–º —ç—Ç–æ–π —Å—Ç—Ä—É–∫—Ç—É—Ä—ã –Ω–∞–∑–Ω–∞—á–µ–Ω. –ê–ª–µ–∫—Å–∞–Ω–¥—Ä –ö—É–±—Ä–∞–∫–æ–≤ - –≤ –Ω–∞—Å—Ç–æ—è—â–∏–π –º–æ–º–µ–Ω—Ç –¥–µ–ø—É—Ç–∞—Ç –í–µ—Ä—Ö–æ–≤–Ω–æ–π –†–∞–¥—ã –æ—Ç –ø–∞—Ä—Ç–∏–∏ ``–°–ª—É–≥–∞ –Ω–∞—Ä–æ–¥–∞``. –î–æ —ç—Ç–æ–≥–æ —Ä—É–∫–æ–≤–æ–¥–∏–ª —Å–µ–∫—Ç–æ—Ä–æ–º –∫–æ–º–º—É–Ω–∏–∫–∞—Ü–∏–π –∏ IT –≤ –û—Ñ–∏—Å–µ —ç—Ñ—Ñ–µ–∫—Ç–∏–≤–Ω–æ–≥–æ —Ä–µ–≥—É–ª–∏—Ä–æ–≤–∞–Ω–∏—è (BRDO), –∫–æ—Ç–æ—Ä—ã–π —Ä–∞–Ω–µ–µ –≤–æ–∑–≥–ª–∞–≤–ª—è–ª –ì–æ–Ω—á–∞—Ä—É–∫. –ö–æ–Ω–∫—É—Ä—Å –ø—Ä–æ–≤–æ–¥–∏–ª—Å—è —Å 25 —Å–µ–Ω—Ç—è–±—Ä—è. –ü—Ä–µ–¥—ã–¥—É—â–∏–π –≥–ª–∞–≤–∞ –£–∫—Ä–∞–≤—Ç–æ–¥–æ—Ä–∞ –°–ª–∞–≤–æ–º–∏—Ä –ù–æ–≤–∞–∫ —É–≤–æ–ª–µ–Ω 1 –æ–∫—Ç—è–±—Ä—è 2019 –≥–æ–¥–∞ –°–æ–æ–±—â–µ–Ω–∏–µ –æ –ø–æ–±–µ–¥–∏—Ç–µ–ª–µ –∫–æ–Ω–∫—É—Ä—Å–∞ –æ–ø—É–±–ª–∏–∫–æ–≤–∞–ª –ü—Ä–∞–≤–∏—Ç–µ–ª—å—Å—Ç–≤–µ–Ω–Ω—ã–π –ø–æ—Ä—Ç–∞–ª. –û—Ç–º–µ—á–∞–µ—Ç—Å—è, —á—Ç–æ –Ω–æ–≤—ã–π –≥–ª–∞–≤–∞ –£–∫—Ä–∞–≤—Ç–æ–¥–æ—Ä–∞ –ø—Ä–∏—Å—Ç—É–ø–∏—Ç –∫ –æ–±—è–∑–∞–Ω–Ω–æ—Å—Ç—è–º –Ω–∞ —Å–ª–µ–¥—É—é—â–∏–π –¥–µ–Ω—å —Å –º–æ–º–µ–Ω—Ç–∞ –Ω–∞–∑–Ω–∞—á–µ–Ω–∏—è. ``–ù–∞–º –≤ –∫–æ–º–∞–Ω–¥–µ –Ω—É–∂–µ–Ω —á–µ—Å—Ç–Ω—ã–π –∏ –ø—Ä–æ—Ñ–µ—Å—Å–∏–æ–Ω–∞–ª—å–Ω—ã–π —á–µ–ª–æ–≤–µ–∫ –≤ —Ä—É–∫–æ–≤–æ–¥—Å—Ç–≤–µ –£–∫—Ä–∞–≤—Ç–æ–¥–æ—Ä–∞. –ì–æ—Å–ø–æ–¥–∏–Ω –ö—É–±—Ä–∞–∫–æ–≤ —É–∂–µ –ø–æ–∫–∞–∑–∞–ª —Å–µ–±—è –∫–∞–∫ –ø—Ä–æ—Ñ–µ—Å—Å–∏–æ–Ω–∞–ª –ø—Ä–∏ —Å—Ç—Ä–æ–∏—Ç–µ–ª—å—Å—Ç–≤–µ —Ç—Ä–∞—Å—Å—ã –ó–∞–ø–æ—Ä–æ–∂—å–µ-–ú–∞—Ä–∏—É–ø–æ–ª—å``, - —Å–∫–∞–∑–∞–ª –ø—Ä–µ–º—å–µ—Ä-–º–∏–Ω–∏—Å—Ç—Ä –ø—Ä–∏ –ø–æ–¥–≤–µ–¥–µ–Ω–∏–∏ –∏—Ç–æ–≥–æ–≤ –∫–æ–Ω–∫—É—Ä—Å–∞.–ü–µ—Ä–≤–æ–æ—á–µ—Ä–µ–¥–Ω–æ–π –∑–∞–¥–∞—á–µ–π –£–∫—Ä–∞–≤—Ç–æ–¥–æ—Ä–∞ –ê–ª–µ–∫—Å–∞–Ω–¥—Ä –ö—É–±—Ä–∞–∫–æ–≤ –Ω–∞–∑–≤–∞–ª –ø–æ–ª–Ω–æ–µ –æ–±–Ω–æ–≤–ª–µ–Ω–∏–µ —Ä—É–∫–æ–≤–æ–¥—è—â–µ–≥–æ —Å–æ—Å—Ç–∞–≤–∞ —Å–ª—É–∂–± –∞–≤—Ç–æ–º–æ–±–∏–ª—å–Ω—ã—Ö –¥–æ—Ä–æ–≥ –≤ –æ–±–ª–∞—Å—Ç—è—Ö, –∞ —Ç–∞–∫–∂–µ —Ä—É–∫–æ–≤–æ–¥—Å—Ç–≤–∞ –ì–ê–ö ``–ê–≤—Ç–æ–º–æ–±–∏–ª—å–Ω—ã–µ –¥–æ—Ä–æ–≥–∏ –£–∫—Ä–∞–∏–Ω—ã``. –ë—É–¥—É—â–∏–π –≥–ª–∞–≤–∞ –£–∫—Ä–∞–≤—Ç–æ–¥–æ—Ä–∞ —Ç–∞–∫–∂–µ –ø–ª–∞–Ω–∏—Ä—É–µ—Ç —Å–¥–µ–ª–∞—Ç—å —Ä–µ–≤–∏–∑–∏—é –ø–æ–¥–≥–æ—Ç–æ–≤–∫–∏ –∫ –∑–∏–º–Ω–µ–º—É —Å–µ–∑–æ–Ω—É –∏ –ø–æ–¥–≥–æ—Ç–æ–≤–∏—Ç—å –ø–ª–∞–Ω—ã –≤–æ—Å—Å—Ç–∞–Ω–æ–≤–ª–µ–Ω–∏—è –¥–æ—Ä–æ–≥ –Ω–∞ 2020 –≥–æ–¥.–í –±–ª–∏–∂–∞–π—à–µ–µ –≤—Ä–µ–º—è, –ø–æ —Å–ª–æ–≤–∞–º –ê–ª–µ–∫—Å–∞–Ω–¥—Ä–∞ –ö—É–±—Ä–∞–∫–æ–≤–∞, —Ç–∞–∫–∂–µ –ø–ª–∞–Ω–∏—Ä—É–µ—Ç—Å—è –æ–±—ä—è–≤–ª–µ–Ω–∏–µ –º–µ–∂–¥—É–Ω–∞—Ä–æ–¥–Ω–æ–≥–æ —Ç–µ–Ω–¥–µ—Ä–∞ –Ω–∞ –¥–æ—Å—Ç—Ä–æ–π–∫—É –∑–∞–ø–æ—Ä–æ–∂—Å–∫–æ–≥–æ –º–æ—Å—Ç–∞ –∏ –ø–æ–¥–ø–∏—Å–∞–Ω–∏–µ –∫—Ä–µ–¥–∏—Ç–Ω–æ–≥–æ —Å–æ–≥–ª–∞—à–µ–Ω–∏—è —Å –ï–ë–†–† –∏ –ï–ò–ë –Ω–∞ –æ–±—â—É—é —Å—É–º–º—É 900 –º–ª–Ω –µ–≤—Ä–æ. –î–ª—è —É–≤–µ–ª–∏—á–µ–Ω–∏—è —Ñ–∏–Ω–∞–Ω—Å–∏—Ä–æ–≤–∞–Ω–∏—è –î–æ—Ä–æ–∂–Ω–æ–≥–æ —Ñ–æ–Ω–¥–∞ –ø—Ä–∞–≤–∏—Ç–µ–ª—å—Å—Ç–≤–æ –±—É–¥–µ—Ç –ø—Ä–∏–≤–ª–µ–∫–∞—Ç—å —Å—Ä–µ–¥—Å—Ç–≤–∞ –∏–Ω–æ—Å—Ç—Ä–∞–Ω–Ω—ã—Ö –ø–∞—Ä—Ç–Ω–µ—Ä–æ–≤. –ö–∞–±–∏–Ω–µ—Ç –º–∏–Ω–∏—Å—Ç—Ä–æ–≤ –Ω–∞–º–µ—Ä–µ–Ω –≤–∑—è—Ç—å –∫—Ä–µ–¥–∏—Ç –Ω–∞ 450 –º–∏–ª–ª–∏–æ–Ω–æ–≤ –µ–≤—Ä–æ –¥–ª—è —Å—Ç—Ä–æ–∏—Ç–µ–ª—å—Å—Ç–≤–∞ –∏ –∫–∞–ø–∏—Ç–∞–ª—å–Ω–æ–≥–æ —Ä–µ–º–æ–Ω—Ç–∞ –¥–æ—Ä–æ–≥. –ü–ª–∞–Ω–∏—Ä—É–µ—Ç—Å—è –ø–æ—Å—Ç—Ä–æ–∏—Ç—å¬† –æ–±—ä–µ–∑–¥–Ω—É—é –¥–æ—Ä–æ–≥—É –õ—å–≤–æ–≤–∞ –∏ —Å–¥–µ–ª–∞—Ç—å –∫–∞–ø–∏—Ç–∞–ª—å–Ω—ã–π —Ä–µ–º–æ–Ω—Ç —Ç—Ä–∞—Å—Å—ã –ö–∏–µ–≤-–û–¥–µ—Å—Å–∞, —Å–æ–æ–±—â–∏–ª –º–∏–Ω–∏—Å—Ç—Ä –∏–Ω—Ñ—Ä–∞—Å—Ç—Ä—É–∫—Ç—É—Ä—ã –£–∫—Ä–∞–∏–Ω—ã –í–ª–∞–¥–∏—Å–ª–∞–≤ –ö—Ä–∏–∫–ª–∏–π. ``–î–ª—è –≤–æ—Å—Å—Ç–∞–Ω–æ–≤–ª–µ–Ω–∏—è —É–∫—Ä–∞–∏–Ω—Å–∫–∏—Ö –¥–æ—Ä–æ–≥ –Ω–µ–æ–±—Ö–æ–¥–∏–º–æ –ø—Ä–∏–≤–ª–µ–∫–∞—Ç—å –¥–æ–ø–æ–ª–Ω–∏—Ç–µ–ª—å–Ω—ã–µ –¥–µ—à–µ–≤—ã–µ —Ä–µ—Å—É—Ä—Å—ã. –°–µ–≥–æ–¥–Ω—è (6 –Ω–æ—è–±—Ä—è - —Ä–µ–¥. ) –ø—Ä–∞–≤–∏—Ç–µ–ª—å—Å—Ç–≤–æ–º –ø—Ä–∏–Ω—è—Ç–æ —Ä–µ—à–µ–Ω–∏–µ –æ –ø—Ä–∏–≤–ª–µ—á–µ–Ω–∏–∏ –∫—Ä–µ–¥–∏—Ç–Ω—ã—Ö —Å—Ä–µ–¥—Å—Ç–≤ –ï–≤—Ä–æ–ø–µ–π—Å–∫–æ–≥–æ –∏–Ω–≤–µ—Å—Ç–∏—Ü–∏–æ–Ω–Ω–æ–≥–æ –±–∞–Ω–∫–∞ –≤ —Ä–∞–∑–º–µ—Ä–µ 450 –º–ª–Ω. –µ–≤—Ä–æ –Ω–∞ —Å—Ç—Ä–æ–∏—Ç–µ–ª—å—Å—Ç–≤–æ –æ–±—ä–µ–∑–¥–Ω–æ–π –¥–æ—Ä–æ–≥–∏ –õ—å–≤–æ–≤–∞ –∏ –∫–∞–ø–∏—Ç–∞–ª—å–Ω—ã–π —Ä–µ–º–æ–Ω—Ç —É—á–∞—Å—Ç–∫–æ–≤ –º–µ–∂–¥—É–Ω–∞—Ä–æ–¥–Ω–æ–π –∞–≤—Ç–æ–º–æ–±–∏–ª—å–Ω–æ–π –¥–æ—Ä–æ–≥–∏ –ú-05 –ö–∏–µ–≤ - –û–¥–µ—Å—Å–∞ (–≤ –ß–µ—Ä–∫–∞—Å—Å–∫–æ–π, –ö–∏—Ä–æ–≤–æ–≥—Ä–∞–¥—Å–∫–æ–π, –ù–∏–∫–æ–ª–∞–µ–≤—Å–∫–æ–π –∏ –û–¥–µ—Å—Å–∫–æ–π –æ–±–ª–∞—Å—Ç—è—Ö)``, -¬† –Ω–∞–ø–∏—Å–∞–ª –ö—Ä–∏–∫–ª–∏–π –Ω–∞ —Å–≤–æ–µ–π —Å—Ç—Ä–∞–Ω–∏—Ü–µ –≤ EURIBOR + 100 bps.``, - —É—Ç–æ—á–Ω–∏–ª –º–∏–Ω–∏—Å—Ç—Ä. –≠—Ç—É –∂–µ –∏–Ω—Ñ–æ—Ä–º–∞—Ü–∏—é –ø–æ–¥—Ç–≤–µ—Ä–¥–∏–ª –ø—Ä–µ–º—å–µ—Ä-–º–∏–Ω–∏—Å—Ç—Ä –ì–æ–Ω—á–∞—Ä—É–∫, –∫–æ—Ç–æ—Ä—ã–π —Å–º–æ—Ç—Ä–∏—Ç –Ω–∞ —ç—Ç–æ —á—É—Ç—å –∏–Ω–∞—á–µ. –ü–æ –µ–≥–æ —Å–ª–æ–≤–∞–º, –Ω–∞ —Ñ–∏–Ω–∞–Ω—Å–∏—Ä–æ–≤–∞–Ω–∏–µ –∏–Ω—Ñ—Ä–∞—Å—Ç—Ä—É–∫—Ç—É—Ä–Ω—ã—Ö –ø—Ä–æ–µ–∫—Ç–æ–≤ —Å—É—â–µ—Å—Ç–≤—É–µ—Ç –º—É–ª—å—Ç–∏–ø–ª–∏–∫–∞—Ç–æ—Ä, —Ç–æ –µ—Å—Ç—å –∫–∞–∂–¥–∞—è –≥—Ä–∏–≤–Ω—è –∏–Ω–≤–µ—Å—Ç–∏—Ä–æ–≤–∞–Ω–∞ –≤ –∏–Ω—Ñ—Ä–∞—Å—Ç—Ä—É–∫—Ç—É—Ä–Ω—ã–µ –ø—Ä–æ–µ–∫—Ç—ã –ø—Ä–∏–≤–µ–¥–µ—Ç –∫ —Å–æ–∑–¥–∞–Ω–∏—é –Ω–æ–≤—ã—Ö —Ä–∞–±–æ—á–∏—Ö –º–µ—Å—Ç, —Ä–æ—Å—Ç—É –±–∏–∑–Ω–µ—Å-–∞–∫—Ç–∏–≤–Ω–æ—Å—Ç–∏ –∏ –¥–æ—Ö–æ–¥–æ–≤ –±—é–¥–∂–µ—Ç–∞.
__label__society St. Mark's Square reopens in Venice, but water remains high VENICE, Italy¬†(AP) - Tourists and residents were allowed back into St. Mark's Square in Venice on Saturday, a day after it was closed due to exceptionally high tidal waters that swept through most of the lagoon city's already devastated center. Despite sunny skies, the city remained on edge due to possibly more wind-propelled high tidal waters during the weekend. The city was struck Tuesday by devastating floods, the worst in decades. Water rose up again in St. Mark's Square on Saturday and the forecast for Sunday was worse. The tide peaked at 1.10 meters (3 feet, 7 inches) above sea level on Saturday at noon, leaving St. Mark's inundated with more than 20 centimeters (8 inches) of water. Late Tuesday, water levels in Venice reached 1.87 meters (6 feet, 1 inch) above sea level, the highest flooding since 1966. The forecast for Sunday was for the high water mark to reach 1.6 meters (5.2 feet) above sea level. On Saturday, tourists sloshed through St. Mark's Square and strolled across it on raised walkways. Many snapped photos of themselves standing in shallow water in front of St. Mark's Square to document their presence during this exceptional high-water season. Museums filled up again with tourists and the city's gondolas were back in business. But the city's museums were expected to shut down on Sunday due to the threat of high water. Luigi Brugnaro, the city's mayor, estimated damages from the flooding would reach at least 1 billion euros ($1.1 billion). He said a final tally of the damage to homes, businesses, stores and the city's rich cultural heritage would be done once the city dries out, according to Italian media. ``Venice is once again being watched by the world and it needs to show that it can succeed and pick itself back up,`` the mayor said in an interview with the Gazzettino and Messaggero newspapers. Brugnaro said Venice was setting up programs to help cover damages sustained by individuals and businesses, noting that families could expect up to 5,000 euros ($5,500) and businesses up to 20,000 euros ($22,000) in aid. He said businesses and individuals suffering even more serious losses could possibly qualify for aid covering up to 70% of damages. Among those recovering from Tuesday's devastating high waters was Sabrina Laggia and her husband. She was blowing dry stone jewelry made by her husband, Alfredo, in their workshop near St. Mark's Square. She was dreading forecasts for more high water on Sunday. ``We have been here 30 years and we have never seen anything like this,'' she said. ``Lots of acqua alta, but never this high.`` ``Acqua alta`` is the term Venetians use to describe flooding from wind-driven high tides. Alfredo said they used to feel safe if the forecast said anything up to 1.4 meters (4.6 feet) ‚Äì about the level they expected Tuesday night only to be surprised when it surged to 1.87 meters without warning. He spent until 2 a.m. Tuesday in their store, named ``Not Just Wine,`` moving his creations to higher positions. But the water reached about 50 centimeters (19.6 inches) in height ‚Äì well above the usual 10 centimeters to 15 centimeters (4 inches to 6 inches). Finally there was no place else to move objects in the tiny workshop. The couple lost an air conditioner and a small soldering gun in the store and a washing machine at their home nearby. Sabrina was rinsing her husband's creations ‚Äì which include filigree bags with velvet detailing and Swarovski crystal-encrusted masks ‚Äì with fresh water and blowing them dry, but she was uncertain if what she was doing will really do the trick against the lagoon's salt water. An employee at another shop, Dorina Balku, was cleaning up Murano glass creations. They lost one large glass fish in the flood that is priced at over 3,000 euros ($3,300) and another large vase. While much of the glass could be cleaned, the jewelry made from the glass beads would have to be taken apart and remade to be salvaged because the fixtures had already corroded from the salty, briny water. ``What can we do? It happened. It is important that people are OK,'' she said. On Thursday, the government declared a state of emergency, approving 20 million euros ($22.1 million) to help Venice repair the most urgent damage. Built on a series of tiny islets amid a system of canals, Venice is particularly vulnerable to a combination of rising sea levels due to climate change coupled with the city's well-documented sinking into the mud. The sea level in Venice is 10 centimeters (4 inches) higher than it was 50 years ago, according to the city's tide office. The flooding has left Italians exasperated at the incompletion of the city's long-delayed Moses flood defense project. Moses consists of a series of moveable barriers in the lagoon that can be raised when high winds and high tides combine to threaten to send ``acqua alta`` rushing across the city. Completion of the multibillion-euro project, under construction since 2003, has been delayed by corruption scandals, cost overruns and opposition from environmentalists worried about its effects on Venice's delicate lagoon ecosystem. ``They need to finish the Moses tomorrow,'' said Sabrina Laggia. ``Not next year.`` ___ Cain Burdeau reported from Castelbuono, Sicily. Copyright 2019 The Associated Press. All rights reserved. This material may not be published, broadcast, rewritten or redistributed.
__label__sport –ö–ª–∞–∞—Å–µ–Ω –∏ –í–∏–Ω—É—Å —Å—Ç–∞–ª–∏ —Ñ–∏–Ω–∞–ª–∏—Å—Ç–∞–º–∏ –ò—Ç–æ–≥–æ–≤–æ–≥–æ —Ç—É—Ä–Ω–∏—Ä–∞ ATP –≤ –ø–∞—Ä–µ –Æ–∂–Ω–æ–∞—Ñ—Ä–∏–∫–∞–Ω–µ—Ü –†–∞–≤–µ–Ω –ö–ª–∞–∞—Å–µ–Ω –∏ –Ω–æ–≤–æ–∑–µ–ª–∞–Ω–¥–µ—Ü –ú–∞–π–∫–ª –í–∏–Ω—É—Å –æ–±—ã–≥—Ä–∞–ª–∏ –∫–æ–ª—É–º–±–∏–π—Ü–µ–≤ –•—É–∞–Ω–∞-–°–µ–±–∞—Å—Ç—å—è–Ω–∞ –ö–∞–±–∞–ª–∞ –∏ –†–æ–±–µ—Ä—Ç–∞ –§–∞—Ä–∞—Ö–∞ —Å–æ —Å—á—ë—Ç–æ–º 6/7(5), 7/6(10), 10:6 –≤ –ø–æ–ª—É—Ñ–∏–Ω–∞–ª–µ –ò—Ç–æ–≥–æ–≤–æ–≥–æ —Ç—É—Ä–Ω–∏—Ä–∞ ATP –≤ –õ–æ–Ω–¥–æ–Ω–µ. –ú–∞—Ç—á –ø—Ä–æ–¥–æ–ª–∂–∞–ª—Å—è 2 —á–∞—Å–∞ 8 –º–∏–Ω—É—Ç. –ó–∞ —ç—Ç–æ –≤—Ä–µ–º—è –ö–ª–∞–∞—Å–µ–Ω –∏ –í–∏–Ω—É—Å –≤—ã–ø–æ–ª–Ω–∏–ª–∏ –¥–µ—Å—è—Ç—å —ç–π—Å–æ–≤, —Ç—Ä–∏–∂–¥—ã –æ—à–∏–±–ª–∏—Å—å –ø—Ä–∏ –ø–æ–¥–∞—á–µ –∏ —Ä–µ–∞–ª–∏–∑–æ–≤–∞–ª–∏ –æ–¥–∏–Ω –±—Ä–µ–π–∫-–ø–æ–π–Ω—Ç, –∞ –∏—Ö —Å–æ–ø–µ—Ä–Ω–∏–∫–∏ —Å–µ–º—å —Ä–∞–∑ –ø–æ–¥–∞–ª–∏ –Ω–∞–≤—ã–ª–µ—Ç, –¥–æ–ø—É—Å—Ç–∏–ª–∏ —Ç—Ä–∏ –¥–≤–æ–π–Ω—ã–µ –æ—à–∏–±–∫–∏ –∏ —Å–¥–µ–ª–∞–ª–∏ –æ–¥–∏–Ω –±—Ä–µ–π–∫. –ó–∞ –≥–ª–∞–≤–Ω—ã–π —Ç—Ä–æ—Ñ–µ–π Nitto ATP Finals –ö–ª–∞–∞—Å–µ–Ω –∏ –í–∏–Ω—É—Å –ø–æ–±–æ—Ä—é—Ç—Å—è –ª–∏–±–æ —Å —Ñ—Ä–∞–Ω—Ü—É–∑–∞–º–∏ –ü—å–µ—Ä–æ–º-–Æ–≥–µ –≠—Ä–±–µ—Ä–æ–º –∏ –ù–∏–∫–æ–ª—è –ú–∞—é, –ª–∏–±–æ —Å –ø–æ–ª—è–∫–æ–º –õ—É–∫–∞—à–µ–º –ö—É–±–æ—Ç–æ–º –∏ –±—Ä–∞–∑–∏–ª—å—Ü–µ–º –ú–∞—Ä—Å–µ–ª–æ –ú–µ–ª–æ.Ôªø
__label__society –î–æ–ø—Ä–æ—Å –∑–∞–¥–µ—Ä–∂–∞–Ω–Ω—ã—Ö —Ä–æ–¥—Å—Ç–≤–µ–Ω–Ω–∏–∫–æ–≤ –∞–ª—å-–ë–∞–≥–¥–∞–¥–∏ –ø—Ä–æ–ª—å–µ—Ç —Å–≤–µ—Ç –Ω–∞ —Å—É–¥—å–±—É –≥–ª–∞–≤–∞—Ä—è –ò–ì* –î–µ–ø—É—Ç–∞—Ç –ì–æ—Å–¥—É–º—ã –Æ—Ä–∏–π –®–≤—ã—Ç–∫–∏–Ω –¥–ª—è iReactor –∑–∞—è–≤–∏–ª, —á—Ç–æ –¥–æ–ø—Ä–æ—Å —Ä–æ–¥—Å—Ç–≤–µ–Ω–Ω–∏–∫–æ–≤ –≥–ª–∞–≤–∞—Ä—è –∑–∞–ø—Ä–µ—â–µ–Ω–Ω–æ–≥–æ –≤ –†–æ—Å—Å–∏–∏ –ò–ì –º–æ–∂–µ—Ç –ø—Ä–æ–ª–∏—Ç—å —Å–≤–µ—Ç –Ω–∞ –∏—Å—Ç–æ—Ä–∏—é —Å –µ–≥–æ ¬´—É–Ω–∏—á—Ç–æ–∂–µ–Ω–∏–µ–º¬ª –∏–ª–∏ –ø–æ–º–æ—á—å —É–∑–Ω–∞—Ç—å –µ–≥–æ –º–µ—Å—Ç–æ–Ω–∞—Ö–æ–∂–¥–µ–Ω–∏–µ. –†–∞–Ω–µ–µ –ê–Ω–∫–∞—Ä–∞ –∑–∞—è–≤–∏–ª–∞ –æ –∑–∞–¥–µ—Ä–∂–∞–Ω–∏–∏ 25 —Ä–æ–¥—Å—Ç–≤–µ–Ω–Ω–∏–∫–æ–≤¬†–ê–±—É –ë–∞–∫—Ä–∞ –∞–ª—å-–ë–∞–≥–¥–∞–¥–∏. –û–Ω –∏–∑–≤–µ—Å—Ç–µ–Ω –∫–∞–∫ –ª–∏–¥–µ—Ä –∑–∞–ø—Ä–µ—â–µ–Ω–Ω–æ–≥–æ –≤ –†–§¬†¬´–ò—Å–ª–∞–º—Å–∫–æ–≥–æ –≥–æ—Å—É–¥–∞—Ä—Å—Ç–≤–∞¬ª1. –û –µ–≥–æ –ª–∏–∫–≤–∏–¥–∞—Ü–∏–∏ –æ–±—ä—è–≤–∏–ª –∞–º–µ—Ä–∏–∫–∞–Ω—Å–∫–∏–π –ª–∏–¥–µ—Ä –î–æ–Ω–∞–ª—å–¥ –¢—Ä–∞–º–ø, –≤—ã—Å—Ç—É–ø–∏–≤ —Å –∑–∞—è–≤–ª–µ–Ω–∏–µ–º 27 –æ–∫—Ç—è–±—Ä—è. –í –±–µ—Å–µ–¥–µ —Å –∫–æ—Ä—Ä–µ—Å–ø–æ–Ω–¥–µ–Ω—Ç–æ–º iReactor¬†–≤–æ–µ–Ω–Ω—ã–π —ç–∫—Å–ø–µ—Ä—Ç —Ñ–æ–Ω–¥–∞ ¬´–ù–∞—Ä–æ–¥–Ω–∞—è –¥–∏–ø–ª–æ–º–∞—Ç–∏—è¬ª –°–µ—Ä–≥–µ–π –ü—Ä–æ—Å—Ç–∞–∫–æ–≤ –æ—Ç–º–µ—Ç–∏–ª, —á—Ç–æ —Å–≤–æ–∏–º __label__society Arrests of 16 Marines in formation at Camp Pendleton for human smuggling ruled unlawful: reports A military judge has ruled the arrests of 16 U.S. Marines¬†accused of¬†human smuggling¬†during a Camp Pendleton¬†Battalion formation were¬†unlawful and a violation of their rights, according to reports. Video of the July mass arrest¬†surfaced last week. The Marines were hauled out of the formation and accused of participating in a scheme to smuggle illegal immigrants into the U.S. from Mexico, according to reports. ‚ÄúIt sends a signal to the government, I‚Äôm not going to tolerate, and we should not tolerate, a command basically imposing the verdict before the court is ever held,‚Äù Bethany Payton-O‚ÄôBrien, an attorney for one of the accused Marines told CBS 8 San Diego. 16 MARINES ARRESTED ON ACCUSATIONS RANGING FROM HUMAN SMUGGLING TO DRUGS, OFFICIALS SAY It‚Äôs unclear, however, what impact the judge‚Äôs ruling will have on the charges against the Marines, the station reported. Charges against three of the 16 Marines were eventually dismissed by prosecutors. The arrests were witnessed by 800 members of the 1st Battalion, 5th Marines, according to reports. ONE MARINE KILLED, SIX HURT IN TRAINING CRASH AT CAMP PENDLETON; SECOND FATAL CRASH SINCE APRIL Payton-O‚ÄôBrien said¬†the arrests were an attempt by commanders to exert unlawful command influence over the case, CBS 8 reported. ‚ÄúThe public humiliation of my client and others in the case was wrong. It was illegal and the Marine Corps' attempt to try to influence the outcome of this case and poison the jury pool,‚Äù she said. CLICK HERE TO GET THE FOX NEWS APP The San Diego Union-Tribune quoted the judge who issued the ruling, Col. Stephen Keane, as rejecting a prosecution argument that the arrests were done during the battalion formation to ensure safety because some of the Marines were suspected of weapons offenses. Fox News' Travis Fedschun contributed to this report.
__label__society –í –ê—Ä—Ö–∞–Ω–≥–µ–ª—å—Å–∫–µ —Å–ª—É–∂–µ–±–Ω–∞—è —Å–æ–±–∞–∫–∞ –ø–æ–º–æ–≥–ª–∞ —Ä–∞–∑—ã—Å–∫–∞—Ç—å –≥—Ä–∞–±–∏—Ç–µ–ª—è –ü–æ–ª–∏—Ü–µ–π—Å–∫–∏–µ –∑–∞–¥–µ—Ä–∂–∞–ª–∏ –≤ –¶–∏–≥–ª–æ–º–µ–Ω—Å–∫–æ–º –æ–∫—Ä—É–≥–µ –±–µ–∑—Ä–∞–±–æ—Ç–Ω–æ–≥–æ —Ä–∞–Ω–µ–µ —Å—É–¥–∏–º–æ–≥–æ –º–µ—Å—Ç–Ω–æ–≥–æ –∂–∏—Ç–µ–ª—è –ø–æ–¥–æ–∑—Ä–µ–≤–∞–µ–º–æ–≥–æ –≤ –≥—Ä–∞–±–µ–∂–µ –ø—Ä–∏ –ø–æ–º–æ—â–∏ –∫–∏–Ω–æ–ª–æ–≥–∞. –ù–∞ —ç—Ç–æ–π –Ω–µ–¥–µ–ª–µ –≤ –ø—Ä–∞–≤–æ–æ—Ö—Ä–∞–Ω–∏—Ç–µ–ª—å–Ω—ã–µ –æ—Ä–≥–∞–Ω—ã –æ–±—Ä–∞—Ç–∏–ª–∞—Å—å 40-–ª–µ—Ç–Ω—è—è –∂–∏—Ç–µ–ª—å–Ω–∏—Ü–∞ –ê—Ä—Ö–∞–Ω–≥–µ–ª—å—Å–∫–∞. –û–Ω–∞ —Ä–∞—Å—Å–∫–∞–∑–∞–ª–∞, —á—Ç–æ –Ω–∞ —É–ª–∏—Ü–µ –ö—Ä–∞—Å–∏–Ω–∞ –∫ –Ω–µ–π –ø–æ–¥–æ—à–µ–ª –º—É–∂—á–∏–Ω–∞ –∏ —Å–∏–ª–æ–π –æ—Ç–æ–±—Ä–∞–ª —Å—É–º–æ—á–∫—É, –≤ –∫–æ—Ç–æ—Ä–æ–π –Ω–∞—Ö–æ–¥–∏–ª–∏—Å—å –¥–µ–Ω—å–≥–∏, –¥–æ–∫—É–º–µ–Ω—Ç—ã –∏ —Å–º–∞—Ä—Ç—Ñ–æ–Ω. –ù–∞ –º–µ—Å—Ç–æ –ø—Ä–æ–∏—Å—à–µ—Å—Ç–≤–∏—è –≤ —Å–æ—Å—Ç–∞–≤–µ —Å–ª–µ–¥—Å—Ç–≤–µ–Ω–Ω–æ-–æ–ø–µ—Ä–∞—Ç–∏–≤–Ω–æ–π –≥—Ä—É–ø–ø—ã –≤—ã–µ—Ö–∞–ª –∫–∏–Ω–æ–ª–æ–≥ —Å —Å–æ–±–∞–∫–æ–π. –ü–µ—Å –ø—Ä–∏–≤–µ–ª –ø–æ–ª–∏—Ü–µ–π—Å–∫–∏—Ö —Å–Ω–∞—á–∞–ª–∞ –∫ —Å—É–º–∫–µ, –∫–æ—Ç–æ—Ä—É—é –≥—Ä–∞–±–∏—Ç–µ–ª—å –≤—ã–∫–∏–Ω—É–ª –Ω–∞ —É–ª–∏—Ü–µ, –∞ –∑–∞—Ç–µ–º –∏ –∫ –¥–æ–º—É, –≥–¥–µ –º–æ–≥ —Å–∫—Ä—ã–≤–∞—Ç—å—Å—è –∑–ª–æ—É–º—ã—à–ª–µ–Ω–Ω–∏–∫. –í—Å–∫–æ—Ä–µ –ø—Ä–µ—Å—Ç—É–ø–Ω–∏–∫ –±—ã–ª –∑–∞–¥–µ—Ä–∂–∞–Ω. –ò–º –æ–∫–∞–∑–∞–ª—Å—è –±–µ–∑—Ä–∞–±–æ—Ç–Ω—ã–π 43-–ª–µ—Ç–Ω–∏–π –º—É–∂—á–∏–Ω–∞, –∫–æ—Ç–æ—Ä—ã–π –∏–º–µ–µ—Ç –Ω–∏ –æ–¥–Ω—É —Å—É–¥–∏–º–æ—Å—Ç—å –∑–∞ –∏–º—É—â–µ—Å—Ç–≤–µ–Ω–Ω—ã–µ –ø—Ä–µ—Å—Ç—É–ø–ª–µ–Ω–∏—è. –ó–∞ –≥—Ä–∞–±–µ–∂ –æ–Ω –º–æ–∂–µ—Ç –æ–∫–∞–∑–∞—Ç—å—Å—è –≤ –∫–æ–ª–æ–Ω–∏–∏ –Ω–∞ —Å—Ä–æ–∫ –¥–æ —Å–µ–º–∏ –ª–µ—Ç, —Å–æ–æ–±—â–∏–ª–∏ –≤ –£–ú–í–î –ø–æ –ê—Ä—Ö–∞–Ω–≥–µ–ª—å—Å–∫–æ–π –æ–±–ª–∞—Å—Ç–∏. #—Ä–µ—Ü–∏–¥–∏–≤–∏—Å—Ç#–≥—Ä–∞–±–µ–∂#–∞—Ä—Ö–∞–Ω–≥–µ–ª—å—Å–∫#—Å–ª—É–∂–µ–±–Ω–∞—è —Å–æ–±–∞–∫–∞
